explicatoryContent.introduction: Being healthy is not just about your body. It is also about how you feel inside. Your mental health is about your thoughts, feelings, and how you handle the ups and downs of life. In this topic, you will learn about mental health, how the media can affect how you see yourself, and how you can help make your community a healthier place for everyone.

keyPoints.heading: What is Mental Health?
keyPoints.content: Mental health is about how you think, feel, and act. When your mental health is good, you feel okay most of the time, you can handle problems, and you can enjoy your life. Everyone has times when they feel sad, worried, or stressed. This is normal. But if these feelings last a long time or stop you from doing everyday things, it might be time to get help.

keyPoints.heading: Looking After Your Mental Health
keyPoints.content: There are many things you can do to look after your mental health. Getting enough sleep, eating well, and being active all help your mind as well as your body. Spending time with friends and family, doing things you enjoy, and talking about your feelings are also important. Taking breaks from screens and social media can help too.

keyPoints.heading: Media and Body Image
keyPoints.content: Body image is how you see and feel about your body. The media shows us lots of pictures of people who look a certain way. But many of these photos have been changed using computers. Skin is smoothed, bodies are made thinner or more muscular, and flaws are removed. These changed photos can make people feel bad about their own normal bodies.

keyPoints.heading: Being Media Smart
keyPoints.content: Learning to spot changed or fake images helps you feel better about yourself. Remember that what you see online is often not real. Everyone's body is different, and that is okay. Instead of comparing yourself to people in ads or on social media, focus on what your body can do and how you feel.

keyPoints.heading: Promoting Health in Your Community
keyPoints.content: You can help make your school and community healthier. Health promotion means sharing messages that help people make healthy choices. This could be making a poster about mental health, talking to friends about body image, or supporting a health campaign. When young people share health messages, other young people often listen.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health and physical health are connected. When you feel stressed or sad for a long time, your body can feel tired and sore. When you are not looking after your body, your mood can suffer. That is why looking after both your mind and body is important.

The media, especially social media, can have a big effect on how young people feel about themselves. Studies show that many young people feel worse about their bodies after looking at social media. This is because they compare themselves to images that have been changed to look perfect. No one really looks like that.

Different cultures have different ideas about what bodies should look like. Some cultures value larger bodies, while others value thinner ones. Some value muscles, others do not. Learning that beauty standards are different around the world can help you see that there is no one right way to look.

caseStudy.title: Lily's Health Campaign
caseStudy.scenario:
Lily is in Year 7. She noticed that lots of her friends follow social media accounts that post pictures of very thin people. Her friends often say mean things about their own bodies after looking at these accounts. Lily learned in class that most of these photos are edited.

Lily decided to do something about it. For a school project, she created a poster that showed a photo before and after editing. The poster said 'What you see is not always real' and explained how photos are changed. She also included tips for feeling good about your body.

Her teacher liked the poster so much that she asked if it could be displayed in the school hallway. Other students started talking about it. Some said they had not realised how much photos were changed. Lily's friend Mei said the poster made her feel better about herself.

Lily felt proud that her small action had made a difference. She started thinking about what other health topics she could share with her school.

extendedAbstract.stem: Predict what might happen to young people's mental health and body image if social media continued to show only edited, perfect images for the next 10 years. What could be done to prevent negative effects?

If social media continued showing only edited, perfect images for 10 more years, we might see more young people struggling with poor body image and mental health issues like anxiety and depression. More people might develop eating disorders or avoid social situations because they feel their bodies are not good enough. Self-esteem might decrease across the whole generation.

To prevent these negative effects, several things could be done: 1) Laws could require labels on edited photos, 2) Schools could teach media literacy so young people can spot fake images, 3) Social media platforms could promote diverse body types and reduce editing filters, 4) More campaigns could celebrate real bodies and achievements rather than appearance, and 5) Young people could follow accounts that make them feel good and unfollow ones that do not.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health is just as important as physical health, but it is often talked about less. Your mental health affects how you think, feel, and behave. It influences how you handle stress, relate to others, and make choices. In this final topic of the Being Healthy series, you will learn about mental health, explore how media affects body image, and discover how you can be part of making your community a healthier place.

keyPoints.heading: Understanding Mental Health
keyPoints.content: Mental health is about your emotional, psychological, and social wellbeing. Good mental health does not mean being happy all the time. It means being able to cope with the normal stresses of life, work productively, and contribute to your community. Everyone experiences times when their mental health is better or worse. Learning to recognise how you are feeling and knowing when to seek help are important skills.

keyPoints.heading: Factors That Affect Mental Health
keyPoints.content: Many things can affect your mental health. These include your relationships with family and friends, what happens at school, how much sleep you get, your physical health, and big life changes or stressful events. Social media and technology use can also affect mental health, both positively (through connection) and negatively (through comparison and overuse). Some factors you can control, and others you cannot.

keyPoints.heading: Media, Beauty Standards, and Body Image
keyPoints.content: The media surrounds us with images of how bodies supposedly should look. These images often represent only a narrow range of body types, and many are digitally altered. When people constantly see these unrealistic images, they may develop negative body image—feeling unhappy with their own normal bodies. Research shows that more time spent on image-focused social media is linked to poorer body image among young people.

keyPoints.heading: Challenging Unrealistic Standards
keyPoints.content: Beauty standards change over time and differ across cultures. What is considered attractive in one place or time may be different elsewhere. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures have their own understandings of beauty that connect to identity, culture, and Country. Recognising that beauty standards are not fixed or universal helps us question the narrow images we see in media.

keyPoints.heading: Being a Health Promoter
keyPoints.content: Health promotion means helping people and communities to be healthier. You can be a health promoter by sharing accurate information, supporting friends who are struggling, challenging stereotypes, and creating positive messages about health. When young people lead health promotion, it can be especially effective because peers often trust and listen to each other.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health and physical health are two sides of the same coin. Your mental state affects your body, and your physical state affects your mind. When you are anxious, your heart might race and your muscles might tense. When you are physically unwell, you might feel down or irritable. Looking after both aspects of health creates a positive cycle.

Body image develops from many influences. Family comments, peer opinions, media images, and cultural messages all shape how you see your body. The problem with media is that it often shows only one type of body as ideal, and even those images are usually edited. This creates an impossible standard that no one can actually meet.

Different cultures have very different ideas about ideal bodies. In some Pacific Island cultures, larger bodies are valued as signs of health and prosperity. In some Asian cultures, there are specific beauty standards related to skin tone and facial features. Aboriginal cultures value connection to Country and community over appearance. Understanding these differences helps us see that beauty standards are created by society, not fixed by nature.

You have more power to influence health than you might think. Research shows that peer-led health promotion can be very effective because young people are more likely to trust and listen to other young people. By talking openly about mental health, challenging unrealistic beauty standards, and sharing accurate health information, you can make a real difference in your community.

caseStudy.title: The R U OK? Day Campaign
caseStudy.scenario:
R U OK? Day is an Australian health promotion campaign that encourages people to ask friends, family, and colleagues if they are okay. It started in 2009 after the founder's father died by suicide, and now millions of Australians participate each year.

At Riverside Secondary College, the student wellbeing committee decided to run R U OK? Day activities. They planned conversation stations where students could practise asking 'Are you okay?' and listening to answers. They created posters with messages like 'A conversation could change a life' and shared facts about mental health.

Student leader Marcus was initially nervous about talking about mental health. He worried people would think it was awkward or uncool. But he decided to be brave and share his own experience of feeling stressed during Year 7 and how talking to a friend had helped.

The response surprised him. Many students approached him afterwards to say they related to his story. Teachers reported that students seemed more willing to talk about their feelings. The school counsellor noticed an increase in students seeking support, which was seen as a positive sign that barriers to help-seeking were being reduced.

Marcus reflected: 'I used to think mental health was something you kept private. Now I realise that talking about it is actually one of the best things you can do, both for yourself and for others.'

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how mental health, body image, and social media are connected. Predict how changes in social media (like new laws requiring labels on edited photos, or new platforms that show less appearance-focused content) might affect young people's mental health and body image in the future.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
Mental health, body image, and social media form an interconnected system. Social media exposes young people to constant images of idealised bodies and lives, which can lead to comparison, negative body image, and poor mental health. Changes to social media could disrupt this cycle.

If laws required labels on edited photos, young people might become more aware of how unrealistic the images are, potentially reducing the impact of comparison. However, labels alone might not be enough—people might still compare themselves even knowing images are edited.

New platforms focusing less on appearance could have more significant effects. If young people spent time on platforms that valued creativity, learning, or connection rather than looks, they might develop identities less tied to appearance. This could improve body image and reduce anxiety related to appearance.

However, change would not be instant. Beauty standards are embedded in culture, not just technology. Young people would still encounter appearance-focused messages in advertising, TV, and peer conversations. Real improvement would require changes across multiple areas: platform design, media literacy education, and broader cultural shifts toward valuing diverse appearances.

In the long term, a combination of platform changes, regulation, and education could lead to improved body image and mental health among young people.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health has moved from a taboo topic to a central concern in health education and public discourse. Understanding what influences mental health, how media shapes our self-perception, and how we can actively promote wellbeing in our communities are essential skills for navigating contemporary life. This final topic in the Being Healthy series brings together your learning about health and wellbeing, empowering you to both look after yourself and contribute to the health of others.

keyPoints.heading: The Dimensions of Mental Health
keyPoints.content: Mental health encompasses emotional, psychological, and social wellbeing. It affects how we think, feel, and act. Mental health exists on a continuum—we can experience periods of flourishing and periods of struggling, and most people move along this continuum throughout their lives. Risk factors (things that increase the chance of poor mental health) and protective factors (things that support good mental health) interact to influence where someone is on this continuum at any given time.

keyPoints.heading: Risk and Protective Factors
keyPoints.content: Risk factors for poor mental health include: family history of mental health conditions, exposure to trauma or abuse, social isolation, academic pressure, bullying, and excessive social media use. Protective factors include: strong relationships with family and friends, sense of belonging, physical activity, adequate sleep, skills for managing emotions, and access to support when needed. Some factors, like genetics, cannot be changed, but many protective factors can be deliberately strengthened.

keyPoints.heading: Media, Beauty Standards, and Body Dissatisfaction
keyPoints.content: Media messages about bodies are pervasive and often problematic. Advertising, entertainment, and social media frequently promote narrow beauty ideals and use digitally altered images. Research consistently links exposure to idealised media images with body dissatisfaction, particularly among adolescents. This dissatisfaction can contribute to disordered eating, excessive exercise, depression, and anxiety. Understanding these effects helps us approach media critically.

keyPoints.heading: Cultural Perspectives on Bodies and Beauty
keyPoints.content: Beauty standards are culturally constructed and vary significantly across time and place. What Western media presents as ideal may differ from beauty standards in Asian, Pacific, African, or Aboriginal cultures. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander understandings of health and identity often emphasise connection to Country, community, and culture rather than physical appearance. Recognising the cultural specificity of beauty standards helps us resist the idea that any single body type is universally ideal.

keyPoints.heading: Challenging Stereotypes and Promoting Inclusion
keyPoints.content: Stereotypes about bodies, gender, and ability can limit how people see themselves and others. Gender stereotypes may discourage boys from expressing emotions or seeking help, and may pressure girls to prioritise appearance. Ability stereotypes may exclude people with disabilities from participation. Challenging these stereotypes—through our language, actions, and the media we create and consume—supports wellbeing for everyone.

keyPoints.heading: Effective Health Promotion
keyPoints.content: Health promotion aims to enable people to increase control over and improve their health. Effective health promotion is evidence-informed, culturally appropriate, and engages the target audience. Young people are particularly well-positioned to lead health promotion activities for their peers because of shared experiences and communication channels. Successful campaigns often combine multiple strategies: awareness raising, skill building, and environmental change.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health and physical health are increasingly recognised as inseparable. The World Health Organization defines health as 'a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease.' This holistic view acknowledges that you cannot be truly healthy if your mental health is suffering, regardless of your physical condition.

The relationship between media and body image has been extensively researched. Studies consistently show that exposure to thin-ideal media increases body dissatisfaction in women, and exposure to muscular-ideal media has similar effects in men. Social media appears to have particularly strong effects because of its personalised, constant, and interactive nature. Unlike traditional media, social media allows endless comparison with peers, not just celebrities.

However, media can also be a force for positive change. Body-positive movements use social media to challenge narrow beauty standards and celebrate body diversity. Mental health campaigns like R U OK?, Beyond Blue, and Headspace use media to reduce stigma and encourage help-seeking. Young people can harness the same platforms that sometimes cause harm to instead promote wellbeing.

Cultural competence is essential in discussing bodies and mental health. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities have holistic understandings of health that include spiritual, cultural, and community dimensions alongside physical and mental health. Asian cultures may have different attitudes toward discussing mental health, shaped by cultural values around family, harmony, and emotional expression. Effective health promotion respects and incorporates these diverse perspectives rather than imposing a single cultural framework.

Your generation has both unique challenges and unique opportunities regarding mental health and body image. You face more media exposure and comparison opportunities than any previous generation. But you also have more access to information, support resources, and platforms for promoting positive change. By understanding the issues and taking action, you can help create healthier communities.

caseStudy.title: The Body Image and Social Media Project
caseStudy.scenario:
A group of Year 8 students at Bayview College decided to investigate how social media affects body image as part of their health class. They surveyed 150 students in Years 7-9, asking about social media use, body satisfaction, and knowledge of photo editing.

The results were concerning: 78% of students reported comparing their appearance to people they saw online, and 62% said this comparison usually made them feel worse about themselves. However, only 35% were confident they could tell when a photo had been digitally altered.

The students decided to create a multi-part intervention. First, they developed a presentation teaching peers how to spot edited photos, including before-and-after examples and information about common editing techniques. Second, they created a social media page sharing unedited photos of real students (with permission) alongside messages about body diversity. Third, they organised a 'Social Media Break Challenge' encouraging students to take a day off from image-focused apps.

The school counsellor, Ms Patel, supported the project and noticed positive effects. 'What made this work was that it came from the students themselves,' she said. 'They understood the issue from the inside and knew how to reach their peers. Some students told me they felt relieved to know others felt the same way.'

Six weeks later, a follow-up survey showed improved ability to identify edited photos (up to 67%) and a slight reduction in negative comparison behaviours.

relational.stem: Explain the relationship between risk factors, protective factors, and the mental health continuum. How do these concepts work together to influence someone's mental health?
relational.modelResponse: Risk factors and protective factors interact to influence where someone is positioned on the mental health continuum at any given time. Risk factors (like stress, isolation, or trauma) push toward the struggling end of the continuum, while protective factors (like strong relationships, adequate sleep, and coping skills) push toward the flourishing end. Neither type of factor acts in isolation—they balance against each other. Someone with many risk factors but also strong protective factors might maintain reasonable mental health, while someone with fewer risk factors but weak protective factors might struggle. This explains why two people experiencing similar challenges may have very different mental health outcomes—their protective factors differ. Understanding this relationship helps us focus on building protective factors, since we cannot always control risk factors.

extendedAbstract.stem: In an increasingly globalised world, Western beauty standards are spreading to cultures that traditionally valued different body types. Analyse the implications of this trend for mental health and body image worldwide, and propose how health promotion might respond.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
The globalisation of Western beauty standards raises significant concerns for mental health and body image worldwide. As media from Western countries spreads through global platforms, communities that once valued diverse body types may increasingly adopt narrow Western ideals. This could lead to rising body dissatisfaction in populations previously protected by local beauty norms, potential increases in eating disorders and mental health issues, erosion of cultural diversity in concepts of beauty, and commercial exploitation as diet and beauty industries expand into new markets.

The implications are particularly concerning for Indigenous communities, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, whose holistic concepts of health and identity may be displaced by appearance-focused Western values. The loss of cultural protective factors could compound existing health disparities.

Health promotion could respond in several ways: supporting local media that celebrates diverse bodies, working with communities to articulate and strengthen their own beauty traditions, developing media literacy programs adapted to different cultural contexts, advocating for regulation of harmful advertising in emerging markets, amplifying diverse voices in global media, and researching body image in non-Western contexts to inform culturally appropriate interventions.

However, responses must avoid cultural paternalism—the assumption that traditional values are always better. Young people in all cultures negotiate multiple influences and make their own meanings. Effective health promotion would support critical thinking and agency rather than simply promoting alternative beauty standards.

Ultimately, the goal should be a world where body diversity is celebrated across all cultures, and no single standard of beauty dominates global consciousness.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Analyses the complex implications of globalising beauty standards across multiple dimensions (cultural, health, commercial). Proposes sophisticated health promotion responses that are culturally sensitive and avoid paternalism. Demonstrates ability to think systemically about global health issues and apply learning to complex scenarios.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health has emerged as one of the defining health challenges of the twenty-first century, with adolescents particularly affected. Media saturation, social media comparison, and persistent stereotypes create a challenging environment for developing positive relationships with our bodies and minds. Yet this challenge also presents an opportunity. Armed with knowledge about what influences mental health and body image, you can both protect your own wellbeing and contribute to healthier communities. This capstone topic synthesises your learning from the Being Healthy series and equips you to take informed action.

keyPoints.heading: The Biopsychosocial Model of Mental Health
keyPoints.content: The biopsychosocial model proposes that mental health is determined by the interaction of biological factors (genetics, neurochemistry, physical health), psychological factors (thoughts, emotions, coping styles, self-esteem), and social factors (relationships, culture, socioeconomic status, life events). This model has replaced simpler views that attributed mental health solely to biology or environment. It explains why the same stressor might lead to depression in one person but not another—their unique combination of biopsychosocial factors produces different outcomes.

keyPoints.heading: Adolescent Mental Health: A Critical Period
keyPoints.content: Adolescence represents a critical period for mental health. The brain undergoes significant development, with the prefrontal cortex (governing decision-making and impulse control) maturing later than the limbic system (driving emotions and reward-seeking). This developmental pattern makes adolescents particularly sensitive to social evaluation, peer influence, and emotional experiences. Many mental health conditions first emerge during adolescence, making this a vital time for prevention, early intervention, and the establishment of healthy patterns.

keyPoints.heading: Media, Internalisation, and Body Dissatisfaction
keyPoints.content: Research has identified internalisation of media ideals as a key mechanism linking media exposure to body dissatisfaction. Internalisation occurs when individuals accept societal beauty standards as their own personal goals. Those who internalise the thin ideal or muscular ideal are more likely to experience body dissatisfaction when exposed to idealised images. This helps explain why some individuals are more affected by media than others—the degree of internalisation moderates the impact. Media literacy interventions aim to reduce internalisation by increasing critical evaluation of media messages.

keyPoints.heading: Intersectionality: Multiple Identities and Wellbeing
keyPoints.content: People do not experience stereotypes about bodies in isolation—they experience them in combination with stereotypes related to gender, ethnicity, sexuality, ability, and other aspects of identity. Intersectionality theory helps us understand how these multiple identities interact. For example, a young Aboriginal woman may face different body image pressures than a white Australian woman, shaped by both Western beauty standards and colonial histories of controlling Aboriginal bodies. Effective health promotion acknowledges these intersections rather than treating body image as a uniform experience.

keyPoints.heading: Health Promotion Theory and Practice
keyPoints.content: Effective health promotion is grounded in theory and evidence. The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion identifies five action areas: building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services. At the individual level, behaviour change theories such as Social Cognitive Theory emphasise self-efficacy, outcome expectations, and observational learning. Ecological models recognise that behaviour is influenced by multiple levels, from individual factors to organisational, community, and policy factors.

keyPoints.heading: Youth-Led Health Promotion
keyPoints.content: Research supports the effectiveness of youth-led health promotion for young people. Peer education leverages social influence, credibility, and shared experience. Young people often have insights into their peers' values, communication channels, and concerns that adults lack. However, youth-led approaches work best when supported by adult expertise and organisational resources. The combination of youth engagement with professional guidance typically produces the strongest outcomes.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
The biopsychosocial model represents a paradigm shift in understanding mental health. Earlier models either attributed mental illness to biological abnormalities (the biomedical model) or to environmental factors (psychosocial models). The biopsychosocial model integrates these perspectives, recognising that biology, psychology, and social context continuously interact. A genetic predisposition might increase vulnerability, but whether this vulnerability leads to a mental health condition depends on psychological factors (coping skills, cognitive patterns) and social factors (support systems, life stressors). This model implies that intervention can occur at any level—medication can address biological factors, therapy can address psychological factors, and social support can address social factors.

Adolescent brain development provides biological context for understanding mental health vulnerability during this period. Neuroimaging research shows that the limbic system, responsible for emotional responses and reward processing, matures earlier than the prefrontal cortex, responsible for rational decision-making and impulse control. This developmental asymmetry helps explain adolescents' heightened emotional reactivity, sensitivity to peer evaluation, and risk-taking tendencies. It also creates windows of both vulnerability and opportunity—negative experiences during this period can have lasting impacts, but positive interventions may be particularly effective.

The media-body image relationship has been extensively researched. Meta-analyses (studies combining results from multiple studies) confirm that exposure to thin-ideal media causes body dissatisfaction in experimental settings. The effect is stronger for women but is also present in men exposed to muscular-ideal media. Social comparison theory explains this effect: people evaluate themselves by comparing to others, and when comparison targets are unrealistically attractive, self-evaluation suffers. The tripartite influence model identifies media, parents, and peers as the three main sources of appearance-related pressures.

Intersectionality, a concept originating in feminist legal scholarship, has become increasingly influential in health research. An intersectional lens reveals that experiences of body image and mental health are shaped by multiple, interacting aspects of identity. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander young people may face unique pressures from the intersection of Western beauty standards and the ongoing impacts of colonisation. Young people from Asian backgrounds may navigate different cultural expectations around appearance and emotional expression. LGBTQ+ young people may face body image pressures specific to their communities. Effective health promotion must attend to these intersections rather than assuming a one-size-fits-all approach.

Health promotion has evolved from simple information provision to sophisticated, multi-level interventions. The Ottawa Charter (1986) established that health promotion requires action across multiple domains, from individual skill-building to policy change. Contemporary health promotion is participatory, involving communities in identifying needs and designing solutions. Youth participation is not just ethically appropriate but strategically effective—young people bring insights, credibility, and networks that adult-designed programs often lack.

caseStudy.title: The Deadly Minds Program: Aboriginal Youth Mental Health Promotion
caseStudy.scenario:
Deadly Minds is a mental health promotion program developed by Aboriginal young people in partnership with Aboriginal community-controlled health organisations and researchers. The program was created in response to concerns about high rates of psychological distress among Aboriginal youth and the perceived inadequacy of mainstream mental health approaches.

The development process began with extensive consultation with Aboriginal young people, Elders, and community members. Participants identified that mainstream mental health messages did not resonate with Aboriginal understandings of health, which encompass connection to Country, culture, family, and community. The term 'social and emotional wellbeing' was preferred over 'mental health' as it better captured the holistic Aboriginal concept of health.

The resulting program incorporated culturally meaningful elements: connection to Country through on-Country activities, cultural activities like art and storytelling, Elders sharing traditional knowledge about wellbeing, peer support from trained Aboriginal youth leaders, and content addressing the specific challenges faced by Aboriginal young people, including racism and intergenerational trauma.

Evaluation showed that Aboriginal young people who participated in Deadly Minds reported improved social and emotional wellbeing, stronger cultural identity, and greater willingness to seek help when needed. The program succeeded because it was designed by and for Aboriginal young people, grounded in cultural knowledge, and delivered in culturally safe environments.

Researcher Dr Williams noted: 'This project showed that effective health promotion must start with community perspectives, not with externally designed interventions. Aboriginal young people knew what they needed—our role was to support them to create it.'

It used culturally appropriate concepts (social and emotional wellbeing) rather than imposing Western frameworks

The program addressed the specific context of Aboriginal young people, including experiences of racism

relational.stem: Explain HOW the biopsychosocial model helps us understand why two people exposed to the same media might have different body image outcomes.
relational.modelResponse:
The biopsychosocial model explains differential outcomes by highlighting the multiple factors that moderate media effects. Biologically, individuals may differ in genetic predisposition to body dissatisfaction or mental health conditions. Psychologically, they may differ in internalisation of beauty standards, self-esteem, comparison tendencies, and coping skills—someone who has not internalised the thin ideal will be less affected by thin-ideal media. Socially, protective factors like supportive family relationships, positive peer networks, and cultural values that do not emphasise appearance can buffer against media effects.

When these factors combine, they produce very different outcomes. One person with genetic vulnerability, high internalisation, low self-esteem, and appearance-focused peers is highly susceptible to negative media effects. Another person without genetic vulnerability, low internalisation, high self-esteem, and supportive relationships may view the same media with minimal impact. The biopsychosocial model helps us see that media exposure is only one factor in a complex system.

Shows understanding of how these factors interact to produce different outcomes for different individuals. Demonstrates relational thinking about the model's explanatory power.

extendedAbstract.stem: The rise of artificial intelligence-generated images threatens to further distort media representations of bodies. Analyse the implications of this technology for mental health and body image, and propose how health promotion might evolve to respond to this challenge.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
AI-generated images represent a qualitative shift in media representation with significant implications for body image and mental health. Unlike edited photos, AI can create entirely fictional 'perfect' people who never existed, making the concept of 'before and after' comparison obsolete. This technology could: produce unlimited idealised images personalised to individual preferences, making them more psychologically impactful; create deepfakes of real people with altered bodies, blurring reality further; reduce effectiveness of current media literacy strategies that focus on identifying editing; and enable new forms of appearance-based harassment and exploitation.

These implications extend beyond individual body image to collective understanding of human appearance. If AI-generated images become ubiquitous, real human bodies may increasingly seem inadequate by comparison. The psychological mechanisms of internalisation and social comparison would still operate, but against targets that are not even real humans.

Health promotion must evolve in several ways. First, media literacy education needs to address AI specifically, teaching recognition of AI-generated images and critical thinking about their prevalence. Second, interventions should shift emphasis from critiquing specific images to building robust self-worth less dependent on appearance. Third, advocacy for regulation of AI-generated content, including labelling requirements and restrictions on certain uses, becomes important. Fourth, promoting diverse, authentic human representation becomes more critical as a counterweight to AI perfection. Fifth, supporting young people to critically evaluate their media environment and curate feeds that support wellbeing remains essential.

Ultimately, AI-generated imagery intensifies existing challenges rather than creating entirely new ones. The fundamental issue—a culture that overvalues appearance and presents unrealistic standards—persists, with AI adding new tools for its perpetuation. Health promotion must address both the specific challenges of AI and the underlying cultural values that make idealised imagery so powerful.

Proposes sophisticated health promotion responses that address both specific AI challenges and underlying cultural issues. Demonstrates ability to apply theoretical frameworks to emerging issues and think creatively about future health promotion.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health and body image exist at the intersection of biology, psychology, culture, and political economy. Understanding these phenomena requires moving beyond simplistic models to engage with the complex interplay of factors that shape how we experience our minds and bodies. This capstone topic synthesises your learning from the Being Healthy series through advanced theoretical frameworks, preparing you not only to protect your own wellbeing but to contribute to scholarly discourse and social change around these critical issues.

keyPoints.heading: Integrating Mental Health Frameworks
keyPoints.content: The biopsychosocial model, while valuable, requires integration with other frameworks for comprehensive understanding. The developmental psychopathology perspective adds temporal and processual dimensions, emphasising how risk and protective factors operate differently across developmental stages. Social determinants of health frameworks highlight structural factors—poverty, discrimination, housing instability—that disproportionately affect marginalised groups. A truly comprehensive model recognises mental health as emerging from the interaction of genes, neurobiology, individual psychology, interpersonal relationships, community factors, and sociopolitical structures, all operating across developmental time.

keyPoints.heading: Social-Cognitive Mechanisms of Media Effects
keyPoints.content: Multiple theoretical mechanisms have been proposed to explain media effects on body image. Social comparison theory (Festinger, 1954) proposes that people evaluate themselves by comparing to others, with upward comparison to attractive targets decreasing self-evaluation. Self-discrepancy theory (Higgins, 1987) suggests that dissatisfaction arises from perceived gaps between actual and ideal self. Objectification theory (Fredrickson & Roberts, 1997) argues that media encourages people, particularly women, to view themselves as objects to be evaluated, leading to habitual self-monitoring and body shame. These mechanisms are not mutually exclusive—research suggests they operate simultaneously and interactively.

keyPoints.heading: The Social Construction of Beauty
keyPoints.content: Beauty standards are neither natural nor universal but are socially constructed through cultural, historical, and economic processes. Foucauldian analysis reveals how beauty norms function as mechanisms of disciplinary power, producing 'docile bodies' that internalise surveillance and self-regulation. Feminist scholarship has documented how beauty standards have historically served patriarchal interests by directing women's time, money, and psychological resources toward appearance. The global beauty industry, valued at hundreds of billions of dollars, has material interests in perpetuating body dissatisfaction.

keyPoints.heading: Postcolonial Perspectives on Bodies
keyPoints.content: Postcolonial theory reveals how contemporary beauty standards are entangled with histories of colonialism and racial hierarchy. The globalisation of Western beauty ideals can be understood as a form of cultural imperialism, with non-Western bodies constructed as inferior or exotic. For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, colonial practices of controlling and disciplining Indigenous bodies—including forced removals, eugenics, and assimilation policies—have ongoing impacts on embodiment and body image. Decolonising approaches to body image involve recovering and valuing Indigenous concepts of the body and wellbeing.

keyPoints.heading: Intersectionality and Embodiment
keyPoints.content: Intersectionality, developed by Kimberlé Crenshaw, provides a framework for understanding how multiple social identities interact to shape experience. Applied to body image, intersectionality reveals that a queer, disabled, Aboriginal young person experiences body image pressures qualitatively differently from a heterosexual, able-bodied, white young person—not as additive separate pressures but as a unique configuration shaped by interlocking systems of power. Effective health promotion must be responsive to this complexity rather than assuming universal experience.

keyPoints.heading: Critical Health Promotion
keyPoints.content: Critical health promotion moves beyond individual behaviour change to address structural determinants of health. Informed by critical theory, it questions whose interests are served by particular definitions of health problems and solutions. It recognises that health promotion can inadvertently reinforce existing power relations—for example, by locating problems in individual behaviour rather than structural conditions, or by imposing dominant cultural values as universal health norms. Participatory approaches that centre the knowledge and agency of affected communities are essential for health promotion that advances equity rather than perpetuating inequality.

The experience of someone at the intersection cannot be understood by looking at each road separately. explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Understanding mental health and body image at an advanced level requires integrating multiple theoretical frameworks, each illuminating different aspects of these complex phenomena.

The biopsychosocial model provides a necessary foundation, but it can be criticised for underspecifying relationships between factors and for potentially obscuring structural determinants by giving equal weight to all domains. Integrating social determinants of health perspectives highlights how factors like poverty, racism, and housing instability—often beyond individual control—profoundly shape mental health outcomes. This integration has political implications: if mental health problems are largely structural, individual-focused interventions are insufficient, and social change becomes a mental health imperative.

Developmental perspectives add crucial temporal dimensions. The differential susceptibility hypothesis proposes that genetically sensitive individuals may be more affected by environmental factors—both negatively (vulnerability) and positively (plasticity). This helps explain why some adolescents exposed to appearance-focused media develop body dissatisfaction while others do not. Adolescence, characterised by heightened neurological sensitivity to social evaluation, may represent a critical period when media effects are particularly powerful.

Theories of media effects have become increasingly sophisticated. Early models proposed direct effects from media exposure to body dissatisfaction. Contemporary models recognise that effects are mediated by psychological processes (internalisation, comparison) and moderated by individual differences (self-esteem, media literacy) and social contexts (peer norms, family attitudes). Objectification theory, developed by feminist psychologists Fredrickson and Roberts, provides a particularly powerful framework. It proposes that environments characterised by sexual objectification lead individuals—particularly women, though increasingly men—to adopt an observer's perspective on their own bodies. This self-objectification is associated with body shame, anxiety, and diminished engagement with internal bodily states.

Critical analysis reveals that body image is not merely an individual psychological phenomenon but is produced through cultural, economic, and political processes. Foucauldian analysis illuminates how beauty standards function as disciplinary mechanisms, producing subjects who internalise surveillance and regulate their own bodies according to norms. The beauty and diet industries profit from body dissatisfaction, creating material interests in perpetuating unrealistic standards. Feminist scholarship has documented how appearance-focused norms function to limit women's opportunities and political power.

Postcolonial perspectives add another layer of analysis. The globalisation of Western beauty ideals occurs within historically produced power relations, with former colonial powers continuing to exercise cultural influence. For Indigenous peoples, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, colonial histories of bodily control have ongoing effects. Decolonising body image involves both critiquing the imposition of Western standards and recovering Indigenous knowledge about bodies and wellbeing.

Intersectionality theory, developed by legal scholar Kimberlé Crenshaw, provides essential tools for understanding how multiple identities shape body image experience. A young, disabled, queer woman of colour experiences body image pressures that cannot be captured by simply adding together pressures faced by women, disabled people, queer people, and people of colour. Her experience is shaped by the unique intersection of these identities within systems of power. Health promotion that ignores intersectionality risks reproducing the experiences of the most privileged within any group as universal.

These theoretical frameworks have practical implications. Critical health promotion moves beyond individual behaviour change to address structural determinants. It involves community participation in defining problems and solutions, attention to power relations, and advocacy for social change. Culturally responsive approaches recognise the diversity of body image experiences and involve affected communities in program development. Evaluation extends beyond individual outcomes to consider community-level and structural changes.

caseStudy.title: Social Media Algorithms and the Commodification of Body Dissatisfaction
caseStudy.scenario:
In 2021, internal documents from a major social media company were leaked to journalists. These documents revealed that the company's own research had found that their platform was harmful to teenage girls' body image, with one internal presentation stating that the platform 'makes body image issues worse for one in three teen girls.'

The documents showed that the company was aware that comparison to unrealistic standards on the platform contributed to eating disorders, depression, and suicidal ideation among young users. However, internal discussions focused on how to manage public relations rather than fundamental platform redesign. Features known to increase body dissatisfaction, like image filters and engagement metrics, were retained because they also increased user engagement and advertising revenue.

The leak prompted congressional hearings and renewed calls for regulation of social media platforms. However, meaningful regulatory change has been slow, with platforms continuing to profit from engagement-optimising algorithms that researchers argue amplify appearance-related content and comparison.

Dr Jasmine Chen, a researcher in digital health, commented: 'This case demonstrates the conflict between corporate profit motives and public health. The platform's business model depends on maximising engagement, and content that triggers social comparison and body dissatisfaction is highly engaging. Without regulatory intervention or alternative platform models, we are relying on corporations to act against their financial interests.'

Meanwhile, young people have developed their own responses. Some engage in 'digital detox' and intentionally curate feeds to exclude appearance-focused content. Others use the same platforms to share body-positive messages and challenge unrealistic standards. Researchers debate whether these individual and grassroots responses can effectively counter the structural power of platform algorithms and the beauty industry.

relational.stem: Explain HOW intersectionality theory changes our understanding of body image compared to approaches that examine gender, ethnicity, or other identities separately.
relational.modelResponse:
Intersectionality fundamentally reframes body image by rejecting the additive approach of examining separate identity dimensions. Traditional approaches might study body image in women, then body image in people of colour, then body image in disabled people, potentially missing experiences at the intersections. Intersectionality proposes that someone at the intersection of multiple identities—say, a disabled Aboriginal young woman—does not simply experience 'female body image pressures' plus 'Aboriginal body image pressures' plus 'disability body image pressures.' Rather, she experiences a unique configuration of pressures produced by the intersection of these identities within interlocking systems of sexism, racism, and ableism.

This has several implications. First, research that studies only one dimension at a time may produce findings relevant mainly to the most privileged within that category (e.g., white women in gender studies). Second, interventions based on single-identity research may fail for those at intersections. Third, understanding body image requires attention to systems of power, not just individual psychological processes. An intersectional approach does not simply add more variables to analysis but fundamentally reconceptualises the phenomenon as shaped by structural power relations.
relational.rubric: Contrasts intersectional and non-intersectional approaches clearly. Explains why intersectionality is not simply 'adding more factors.' Demonstrates understanding of how multiple identities interact rather than add. Connects to systems of power. Shows how this changes both understanding and intervention approaches.

extendedAbstract.stem: The social media case study reveals how corporate interests can conflict with public health. Drawing on critical theory, analyse how the political economy of digital media platforms shapes body image at a population level, and theorise what forms of social and political change might be necessary to address these structural determinants.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
The political economy of digital media platforms creates structural conditions that systematically harm body image at a population level. Platforms operate under surveillance capitalism, where user engagement generates data that is sold to advertisers. Algorithms are optimised to maximise engagement, not wellbeing. Content that triggers emotional responses—including the negative emotions produced by social comparison and body dissatisfaction—often generates high engagement. Thus, the business model has no intrinsic mechanism to limit harmful content and indeed incentivises its proliferation.

The beauty and diet industries, representing hundreds of billions in annual revenue, are major advertisers on these platforms. Their commercial interests lie in producing body dissatisfaction, which drives consumption of their products. Platforms profit from delivering these advertisers access to users experiencing the very dissatisfaction the advertisers cultivate. This creates a symbiotic relationship between platform capitalism and the beauty industry, with body dissatisfaction serving the interests of both.

Foucauldian analysis reveals these platforms as mechanisms of disciplinary power that extend beyond traditional media. Users internalise surveillance, curating and monitoring their own images and bodies for the anticipated gaze of others. This self-surveillance serves platform interests by generating engagement and content, while psychologically harming users through the constant self-objectification it produces.

Addressing these structural determinants requires interventions beyond individual behaviour change. Regulatory approaches might include: mandatory algorithmic transparency, allowing researchers to study how content is amplified; bans on certain advertising practices that target body dissatisfaction; platform liability for harms caused by algorithmic amplification; data protection that limits surveillance capitalism; and public investment in alternative platform models prioritising wellbeing over engagement.

More fundamental change might require challenging the commodification of attention itself. This could involve: new economic models for digital services not reliant on advertising; democratic governance of digital infrastructure; anti-trust action to reduce platform power; and cultural shifts that devalue appearance-focused social media use. These changes require collective action—social movements, political organising, and perhaps new institutional forms.

Critically, such change must be attentive to power. Regulation drafted by those with interests in the status quo may be ineffective. Platform corporations have substantial lobbying power and influence over political discourse. Genuine change likely requires sustained pressure from affected communities and civil society, holding both corporations and governments accountable.

Ultimately, addressing the body image harms of digital platforms is not merely a health issue but a question of democratic governance of powerful technologies. It requires understanding platforms not as neutral tools but as political-economic systems with interests, and mobilising countervailing power to redirect them toward human flourishing.
